note: Initial technique catalog derived from CFPF paper and appendix. IDs are FLAME-assigned pending official FS-ISAC numbering.

P1.name: Recon
P1.description: Threat actor determines target, collects information, and sets up infrastructure.

techniques.name: Search engine malvertising
techniques.description: Purchase of search engine ads targeting banking/financial keywords to redirect victims to spoofed login pages.
indicators: Spoofed domain in ad destination URL

techniques.name: SEO poisoning
techniques.description: Manipulation of search engine results to surface malicious sites impersonating legitimate financial institutions.
indicators: Anomalous search result rankings for brand terms
Newly indexed domains mimicking financial institutions

techniques.name: Lookalike domain registration
techniques.description: Registration of domains that visually resemble legitimate financial institution domains via typosquatting, homoglyphs, or TLD variations.

techniques.name: Dark web reconnaissance
techniques.description: Acquisition of stolen credentials, PII, or financial data from dark web marketplaces for use in account takeover or synthetic identity fraud.

techniques.name: Social media reconnaissance
techniques.description: Collection of target information from social media profiles — employer, role, business relationships — to support social engineering.
indicators: Connection request patterns from suspicious accounts

techniques.name: Callback infrastructure setup
techniques.description: Establishment of phone numbers, VoIP services, and caller ID spoofing capability to support vishing operations.

techniques.name: Credential marketplace acquisition
techniques.description: Purchase of valid credentials from initial access brokers or infostealer log marketplaces.
indicators: Credentials matching corporate email domains in stealer logs

techniques.name: Target list compilation
techniques.description: Assembly of target lists from public records, business directories, regulatory filings, or purchased data for mass-targeting campaigns.
indicators: Unusual access to public company databases

P2.name: Initial Access
P2.description: Threat actor gains foothold against consumer, institution, or third party.

techniques.name: Credential harvesting via spoofed page
techniques.description: Victim enters credentials on a convincing replica of their financial institution's login page. May include real-time MFA token relay.
indicators: Login attempts from known phishing infrastructure

techniques.name: Vishing (voice phishing)
techniques.description: Phone-based social engineering where actor impersonates bank staff, law enforcement, or government agency to extract credentials, MFA tokens, or authorization for account changes.
indicators: Spoofed caller ID matching institution numbers
Call center interaction preceding account changes

techniques.name: Smishing (SMS phishing)
techniques.description: Fraudulent SMS messages impersonating financial institutions to direct victims to credential harvesting pages or elicit direct responses with sensitive information.
indicators: Bulk SMS from spoofed short codes
URLs in SMS pointing to newly registered domains

techniques.name: Email phishing / spearphishing
techniques.description: Targeted or bulk email campaigns impersonating financial institutions, vendors, or business partners to deliver credential harvesting links or malware.

techniques.name: Credential stuffing
techniques.description: Automated use of stolen credential pairs from unrelated breaches to test login access across financial platforms.

techniques.name: SIM swap
techniques.description: Social engineering or insider compromise at mobile carrier to transfer victim's phone number to actor-controlled SIM, intercepting MFA codes.
indicators: MFA delivery to new device preceding account changes

techniques.name: Business email compromise
techniques.description: Compromise or spoofing of business email accounts to impersonate executives, vendors, or partners for fraudulent payment authorization.

techniques.name: Synthetic identity creation
techniques.description: Fabrication of a new identity using a combination of real and fictitious PII to open new accounts or establish credit.

techniques.name: Insider access abuse
techniques.description: Malicious use of legitimate employee access to financial systems, either by a rogue insider or through coercion/bribery.
indicators: Access to accounts outside normal responsibilities

techniques.name: Malware / infostealer
techniques.description: Installation of malware on victim's device to capture credentials, session cookies, or banking information.

P3.name: Positioning
P3.description: Threat actor changes or collects account information for forwarding to controlled infrastructure.

techniques.name: Add authorized user
techniques.description: Addition of actor-controlled identity as authorized user on the compromised account.
indicators: New user additions from unusual IP/device
Temporal correlation with social engineering events

techniques.name: Modify beneficiary / payee information
techniques.description: Changes to wire transfer beneficiaries, ACH recipients, or payment routing to direct funds to actor-controlled accounts.
indicators: Changes followed by immediate wire requests

techniques.name: Modify contact information
techniques.description: Changes to email, phone, or mailing address to prevent legitimate account holder from receiving transaction alerts or correspondence.
indicators: Contact info changes from new devices/IPs

techniques.name: Disable or redirect alerts
techniques.description: Modification of notification preferences to suppress transaction alerts, balance notifications, or security warnings.
indicators: Alert preference changes from unusual sources

techniques.name: Register new MFA device
techniques.description: Enrollment of actor-controlled device for multi-factor authentication to maintain persistent access.
indicators: New device enrollment from unusual location
Multiple MFA devices registered in short period

techniques.name: Increase transaction limits
techniques.description: Request or modification of daily transaction limits, wire transfer thresholds, or credit limits to enable larger fraudulent transactions.
indicators: Limit increase requests from new channels

techniques.name: Email forwarding rule
techniques.description: Creation of email forwarding or inbox rules to intercept communications and maintain visibility into victim's correspondence.
indicators: New forwarding rules to external addresses
Rules auto-deleting messages from specific senders

techniques.name: Data exfiltration for fraud setup
techniques.description: Collection of account details, transaction history, contact lists, or vendor relationships to support convincing impersonation in later phases.
indicators: Unusual API queries against account data

P4.name: Execution
P4.description: Threat actor converts stolen data or access to money through business procedures.

techniques.name: Unauthorized wire transfer
techniques.description: Initiation of wire transfers to actor-controlled accounts using compromised access or fraudulent authorization.

techniques.name: Unauthorized ACH origination
techniques.description: Initiation of ACH debits or credits to move funds to actor-controlled accounts.

techniques.name: Check fraud
techniques.description: Issuance of unauthorized checks, alteration of legitimate checks, or creation of counterfeit checks using compromised account information.

techniques.name: Fraudulent invoice submission
techniques.description: Submission of fraudulent invoices or modification of legitimate invoices to redirect payments to actor-controlled accounts.
indicators: Duplicate invoices with different payment details

techniques.name: Payroll diversion
techniques.description: Modification of direct deposit information to redirect employee payroll to actor-controlled accounts.
indicators: Direct deposit changes from unusual sources
Multiple employee changes in short period

techniques.name: Fraudulent insurance claim
techniques.description: Submission of fabricated, exaggerated, or staged insurance claims to extract payment from insurance carriers.
indicators: Claim patterns inconsistent with historical baseline

techniques.name: Loan/credit application fraud
techniques.description: Use of stolen or synthetic identities to apply for loans, credit cards, or lines of credit with no intent to repay.

P5.name: Monetization
P5.description: Method of payment transferring stolen funds to threat actor's control.

techniques.name: Domestic wire to mule account
techniques.description: Wire transfer to a domestic account controlled by a money mule, who further distributes funds.

techniques.name: International wire transfer
techniques.description: Wire transfer to accounts in foreign jurisdictions, often in countries with limited bilateral recovery agreements.
indicators: No prior international wire history for account

techniques.name: Cryptocurrency conversion
techniques.description: Conversion of stolen funds to cryptocurrency via exchanges, peer-to-peer platforms, or Bitcoin ATMs to obscure the money trail.
indicators: Bitcoin ATM activity near mule account locations

techniques.name: Cash withdrawal network
techniques.description: Coordinated ATM withdrawals or over-the-counter cash withdrawals from mule accounts, often across multiple branches/locations simultaneously.
indicators: Geographically dispersed withdrawals from same account

techniques.name: Prepaid card loading
techniques.description: Transfer of stolen funds to prepaid debit cards or gift cards, which are then used for purchases or resold.
indicators: Multiple card loads from same source
Card usage patterns inconsistent with legitimate use

techniques.name: Trade-based laundering
techniques.description: Use of over- or under-invoiced trade transactions to move value across borders while disguising the origin of funds.
indicators: Trade values significantly deviating from market rates

techniques.name: Digital payment platform transfer
techniques.description: Movement of funds through digital payment platforms (Zelle, Venmo, PayPal, CashApp) to layer transactions and complicate tracing.
indicators: New payee additions on P2P platforms
P2P transfers to newly created accounts
